item.title: Scybernethic(s) Summary
item.dc:creator: Christophe_Rigon
item.content:encoded:
Christophe Rigon's "Scybernethic(s)" is a personal framework integrating diverse fields to understand cognition and self-transformation. Rigon's methodology blends iterative cycles of theory and practice, utilizing mind-mapping and computer simulations alongside phenomenological inquiry. He emphasizes the interconnectedness of knowing and being, proposing a second-order rationality that accounts for the observer's role. The framework challenges traditional epistemologies, advocating for a deeper understanding of the world and ourselves, and promoting a more participatory approach to knowledge. The texts present both a theoretical overview and Rigon's personal journey in developing this unique perspective.

What is scybernethic(s)?

Scybernethics, as discussed in the article, is an approach that seeks to unite the dualities of mind and body, subject and object, and self and world, through an existential enaction of creative cognition and technological hermeneutics. This approach recognizes that cognition and life are interrelated and aims to cultivate a second-order rationality that promotes ethical and meaningful engagement with the world. In essence, scybernethics is an attempt to forge a new way of being in the world that acknowledges our interconnectedness with the environment and each other, and seeks to bridge the gap between subjective experience and objective reality.

Prolegomena

The author proposes the use of the enactive paradigm as a tool for exploring the relationship between a professional cognitive scientist/philosopher and their own common sense. The author is trained in biology and cognitive sciences and views all paradigms and theories as different ways of seeing and thinking. A preceding study by Claire Petitmengin has explored the process of intuition using a combination of first and second person perspectives and meditation. The author proposes an original approach to these questions, combining enactive thinking and knowledge/cognitive technologies for self-transformation on a scientific, epistemological, and existential level, which the author refers to as an "ars." The author views enaction as a reflexive and lived form of self-awareness, and a technology and aesthetic of the self.

1. Introduction

The author is writing from a Varelian inspired enactive paradigm and has a background in biological (techno)science and a personal interest in the questions of "What is life?" and "How to think differently?" He has developed a concept of "creative cognition" through research in enactive and second-order cybernetic perspectives and will present his approach in the text, including his understanding of models and computer simulations. He will also introduce his "prototypical experiential device" and how he used a combination of scholarship and self-writing to design a formal genetical ontology. The author will also discuss his personal approach to computer simulations of artificial cognition as an "experimental epistemology" and the importance of Parallel and Distributed Processing models.

2. Drawing a distinction - creative cognition, intuition and body sense-making

The author is discussing "creative cognition," which refers to the experience of creating meaningful concepts in our consciousness. He is specifically addressing the "know-what" aspect of this process, which is generated by the implicit "know-how." He note that intuition is not considered as evidence, but rather as a complex process between the self, valid scholarly knowledge, and computer simulations of artificial cognition. The author also mentions two other interesting aspects of creative cognition, including the coordination of the sensory-motor loop and body acting in the environment and the concept of living in a "philosophical body." He mention two works in this field, Richard Shusterman's somato-aesthetics and Evan Thompson's enaction.

3. Methodological strategy

3.1 About second-order thinking

The author introduces a graphical convention of using "concept²" to represent second-order concepts or notions. Second-order concepts are not just "the concept of the concept" but also "the conceptualization itself" in relation to "the concept of the conceptualizer." This leads to a self-transforming and embodied knowledge experience. The author also introduces the "ambijective gesture," which is the internal gesture of co-determining the objective and subjective polarities of any distinction in the act of knowing. This results in a formalization cyclic process that is a re-appropriation and re-presentation of implicit self-knowledge. The author concludes by mentioning that they will delve deeper into second-order thinking and complement it with a dialectical approach later in the text.

3.2 Important ethical and methodological tools

3.2.1 Homeostasis

The author uses the word "homeostasis" as a metaphor for the slight imbalances in our biological balance that make us alive and sensitive beings.

3.2.2 Suspension of judgement and excluded middle

The author learned about the idea of suspension of judgement from a science fiction novel in their youth and has come to understand it as a tool for re-equilibrating the Aristotelian "excluded middle," which was introduced to neutralize subjectivity and relativism in pursuit of valid knowledge. The author notes that this idea has evolved over time and that questions about the role of the observer and technology in the scientific process still remain today.

3.2.3 Levels of abstraction (and the “technology by itself” view subterfuge)

The author argues that the distinction between hardware and software in technology is a modern myth created by the accumulation of abstract layers of different programming languages. This leads to a confusion between the two levels and the idea of a machine being "intelligent" without considering the observer-actor involved in the equation. The author also points out that this view is perpetuated in the public space by techno-marketing and transhumanist rhetoric. The author believes that this understanding provides a way to think about the mind-body problem of consciousness, by considering the levels of abstractions involved and the impact of historical and cultural self-decentering technologies on it.

3.2.4 Gestalt-shifting character and point of view flexibility

The author believes that people often have unique perspectives and backgrounds that shape their views and that there is often implicit knowledge for complex reasons. The author also states that they are not an iconoclast.

3.2.5 Searching and modelizing “without representations and finality”

The author argues that the dominant cognitivist culture, expressed as a focus on problem solving, is so deeply ingrained in our thinking that it may seem counter-intuitive to let go of preconceived ideas. However, the author believes that in order to do science effectively, we must deprive ourselves of these preconceived ontologies. The author instead advocates for an "enactive perspective" where representations and finality are seen as being enacted by the subject's activity in relation to the inquiry process, rather than being driven by external constraints. To truly understand the cognitivist problem-solving perspective, the author suggests considering its production context and adopting a "creative cognition" approach that explicitly deals with the first-person/third-person relationship in techno-science.

3.2.6 Cognitivism vs. enaction: and the winner is…?!

The author was first drawn to enaction because it offered a more comprehensive and integrative approach to cognition compared to cognitivism which focused more on the intellectual and socially normative side. The author is influenced by the cognitivist side of cognition but tries to approach it in a more hermeneutical way and considers it only as a possible way of thinking, not a normative one. The author believes that two main elements of cognitivist style are linear thinking and localization of representation, but challenges these through distributed representations and processual thinking which lead to functional thinking. The linear thinking style can be subverted through iterative second-order thinking cycles and a hermeneutic approach, leading to self-understanding and creative epistemological insights.

3.2.7 About enactive modelizing and simulations: “From computers which think to computers which make me think”

The author expresses gratitude to philosophers Bernard Stiegler and scholars inspired by Simondon for providing them with philosophical tools to think about and express their own experience with the technical dimension. The author also highlights the importance of considering the impact of technology on our lives and avoiding a return to a repressed state of technology. The author developed their modelization skills by studying biology, systemics, cybernetics and complex models. They see models and computer simulations as experimental and experiential tools and believe in the co-determination of the theoretics with its attentional object and methodology. The author also integrates the classical hypothetical-deductive/empirical scientific methodology with auto-phenomenological inquiry through the model/computer simulation loop. However, the author acknowledges that they could not develop their approach in real intersubjective empirical practices.

3.3 Functions as enacted iterations: an analytical of dynamical approaches

The author is discussing how computer science and PDP simulations have taught them to think in terms of iterative processes and analogical thinking. They also mention that functional computer simulations, even if done in a linear fashion, simulate a quasi-parallel processing, which can be used for our own edification. The author also mentions the relationship between analog and digital concepts in the field of techno-philosophy and cybernetics.

3.4 From dialectics tension to dialogics thinking: coping homeostatically and patiently with conceptual dipoles

The author proposes a practical approach to deal with the dialectical tension based on his own experience, following a previous proposal for an Hegelian inspired "neurodialectics" in the enactive field.

3.4.1 Conceptual dipoles

The author notes the importance of "conceptual dipoles" in structuring disciplinary theories and cognitive domains. These are two complementary or opposing linguistic terms, represented by a slash "/". Examples include "linearity / circularity", "space / time", and "third person / first person point of views". The author has developed their own creative approach to dealing with these concepts, and notes differences with the definitions put forth by Varela, who used similar concepts in his work. The author also mentions that Bateson used a similar slash notation in a different context.

3.4.2. The asymmetrical nature of the dipole and the ethical (self)imperative

The author always perceived a fundamental asymmetry between the two terms, where one was easier to define and the other was unclear. The author's focus is on the "weak" side of the dipole, which is more difficult to grasp. However, excessive polarization in controversy tends to favor the "easy" polarity, which is more in agreement with the mechanical structure of causal explanations and expelling the subjective understanding.

3.4.3 The two distinctions in one

The author has noticed the importance of "conceptual dipoles" (two complementary or opposing linguistic terms) in structuring theories and cognitive domains. They have perceived a fundamental asymmetry between the two terms in a dipole, with one being "easy" to define and the other being more subjective and difficult to grasp. The author suggests adopting a second-order strategy by coupling and cycling between a long meta-epistemological and short phenomenological pathway to overcome the "blinding proximity of reality." They also reject the idea of "quantum cognition" as a deceptive application of a mathematized concept to a specific object domain and a lack of ethical recognition of the subjectivity of science.

3.4.4 A systematical logic of knowledge exploration: in search for invariants, prototypical scheme and correlations

The author describes a method called "dialogic" introduced by Morin in 1986 which involves exploring a conceptual dipole (pair of opposing concepts) systematically. The method consists of understanding the two concepts distinctly, then together in their complementarity and context. The generated conception is then checked against valid scholarly knowledge to form a valid meta-perspective. The author emphasizes the importance of not accepting the paradoxical tension of the dipole immediately and instead keeping it in suspension to allow for embodied understanding to emerge. The process of accumulating suspensions can become complex and anxiogenic, so the author suggests using an hypomnemata as a tool to release pressure. The author believes that the body should guide and make the semantic synthesis, not the intellectual mind, by respecting one's own homeostatic rhythms and being patient. The author describes this process as an educated thinking body that is not an impulse but a conscious and intelligent process leading to temporary semantic revelations. The author also mentions that this experience can be described as an aesthetic feeling of resolution and the reasonings gradually become like dances in space. The author believes this praxis is coherent with the "coupling approach" of Enactivism in philosophy.

4. Prototypical experiential device

4.1 My “Brain” and designing a reflexive genetical ontology: a first person enactive style of representing

The author's "brain" is a mind-mapping tool called a semantic net, but they wanted something with more freedom in dimensionality. He chose a commercial product that offers a 2D hierarchical representation of items, but with the ability to make free relational links. Their "brain" contains 20,000 items organized in a way that is only decipherable by the author. It can be explored online at the link provided and has a search engine. It is a chronologically dated trace of the author's learning and thinking and could one day be used to backtrack their thinking as an archaeologist. There is also a collaborative version of this software.

4.2 Models and simulation of a-cognition: the reflexive heuristics / hermeneutical cycle of representations in action

The author describes the "hermeneutics of technology" approach to observing and accessing the internal dynamics of artificial agents and robots. By simulating these agents and embedding them in an evolutionary algorithm, one can study the viability of the agent. The author also describes the view of artificial cognition as experiential epistemology, where one can experiment with the "anthropological constitutive polarity of the technics" by linking their knowledge of the dynamics to their own internal gestures. This approach leads to new attentional perspectives and reinitializes the hermeneutical and heuristic cycles. The author calls this living phenomenological experience of the technics "tekhnicus," inspired by Bourdieu's habitus. The author also discusses the influence of works by Bachimont, Winograd and Flores, Hutchins, and Zovko. This understanding led the author to converge towards the distributed and parallel processing paradigm and to stabilize a dynamical internal gesture as a form of enacting.

5. Enacted results - regulative patterns and rhythms

5.1 Ceteris paribus (natural sciences) / mutatis mutandis (human and social sciences)

The author's methodologies and ethical/deontological commitments can be interpreted as arising from both natural science and human/social science epistemologies. This is not surprising as the author is part of the cognitive domain being studied. The process can be compared to the concept of "double hermeneutics" in social sciences and to the idea of "causes and conditions" in Buddhist philosophy.

5.2 First trivial emergence

The author's first discovery was the emergence of a trinity of intellectual thinking, language, and body in their phenomenological understanding. This realization showed that even when trying to avoid projecting pre-conceptual categories, these categories still emerged as meaningful from their eclectic practices, leading the author to trust in their self-knowing process.

5.3 The enacted quasi-bidimensional formal prototype

The author found a "formal quasi-bidimensionality" in their practices, which was a meaningful pattern that couldn't be reduced to a clear context. The author found correlations with "double intentionality" in other works and is still trying to understand the meaning of "intentionality." He believe intentionality is a fundamental and primordial bio-conscious gesture, rather than a defined and formalized form.

5.4 Relational thinking without relational realism: an indirect question to Simondon’s approach

The author discusses the emergence of a "formal quasi-bidimensionality" in their practice, which refers to a pattern of a clear formal dimension and an unclear orthogonal dimension that cannot be reduced to the formal dimension. This pattern was stabilized into a "quasi-quadrilectic schemata" or diagrammatization, which represented knowledge in the form of a cubic matrix. However, the author found that the schema was missing aspects of the problematic and needed to be added onto for further depth, resulting in a fractal effect of self-reflection. The author found that the aesthetic feeling of their discovery strategy followed a spiral shape, linked to the golden proportion, which confirmed their understanding of the analogy of proportionality as a ratio of ratios. The author found the best explanation of the form in Thomas Aquinas, who said that being is analogous and not univocal or equivocal, but a proportionality analogy. The author concludes that relation is deconstructed and driven towards a "groundless ground" realm.

5.5 From the cybernetics of the cybernetician to second-order enaction

The article discusses second-order thinking and how it could be applied to second-order enaction or enaction². Second-order enaction involves "an enaction of enaction" and "an enaction of the enacting," leading to "the enaction of the enactor." The article suggests taking a detour through the "long" (meta)epistemological pathway and the "short" phenomenological pathway to approach this concept.

5.6 Enacting reflexive thinking : the circle quadrature, the uroboros / Moebius ribbon and hacker ethics

The author discusses second-order thinking as a tool to deconstruct formal thinking and move towards the "processual dimension". This involves becoming aware of cognitive blind spots and uncovering the implicit conditions of knowledge production. The process leads to new conceptions and research in an infinite circle of production, and is limited by our own finitude and limits.

5.7 Form / Processus: taking care of the pharmakon (gestures and orthopraxis)

The author proposes a practical definition of "form" as anything that can be mentally or physically designated, which is related to the concept of eigenform and the idea of meaningful gestalt. The "processual dimension" of an object or phenomenon cannot be fully formalized and is best understood as a mix of flux, ambiguity, and subjective feeling. The distinction between a "process" and a "processus" is important, as the former is an incomplete or reduced form of the latter. The processual dimension is what makes life fundamentally unobjectifiable and points to a limit of direct approach by classical scientific reason, but can be explored through iterative first-hand lived experience. The author draws parallels with concepts such as phenomenological intentionality and "patterns that connect" and suggests that understanding the processual dimension requires a nuanced, disciplined ana-logical process.

5.8 The dialectical transduction between dipole polarities

The author notes the importance of ethical considerations when importing models or paradigms from one field to another, particularly between natural and social sciences or between natural science and technology. They discuss the idea of "transduction" between forms and processes and how it relates to changes in perspective or level of abstraction. The concept of the "zigzag" model, as used by Bateson and Gendlin, is introduced as an example. The author also notes historical shifts between knowledge-based normative constraints and technological advancements.

5.9 The surplus of meaning and the necessary defect

The "processual dimension" is a non-objectifiable and incalculable aspect of cognition that is necessary for sense-making. It is similar to Varela's concept of the "imaginary" dimension that induces a surplus of meaning and is the mother of intentionality. This dimension is also present in Stiegler's idea of the necessary defect and in Buddhism's concept of Śūnyatā, which is not a form of nothingness but a philosophical tool to guide meditative practice. The author warns against the instrumentalization of relational realism by the techno-industry to justify the emergence of "thinking machines." Meditative techniques are a way to tame and understand this processual dimension, which is the "mother of sense-making." The reader should consider the author's "ambijective gesture" and "dialogical dialectics" when interpreting this concept.

5.10 From “artificial neural nets” to models of phenomenological intentionality

The author discusses the emergence of the sciences of cognition and the significance of the (neo)connectionist approach in cognitive science. The approach, represented by the PDP (Parallel and Distributed Processing) model, can be understood as distributed representation and/or distributed processing, exhibiting cognitive-like properties. The author argues that the PDP model can be interpreted as a dynamical model of the ontological-being side of phenomenological intentionality, which provides a solution to the "Moebius" formal turn of the ribbon, or the explanatory gap between cognitive emergences and the biological substratum.

5.11 From a mathematical theory of communication without semantical dimension toward the living process of in-formation

The article discusses Claude Shannon's contributions to the field of information theory, including his application of Boolean algebra to electrical circuits and his 1948 article "A Mathematical Theory of Communication" which is considered the founding article of the new "theory of information". Shannon's conception of information was not related to semantics, but rather focused on signal transmission and statistical abstraction. This abstract theory of information is important to consider when studying autonomous cognitive entities and intelligent living beings. Shannon was also one of the four initiators of the 1956 Dartmouth Summer Research Project on Artificial Intelligence, which is considered the founding event of the AI perspective.

5.12 From computers in nature to the nature of automatic computing machines

The author discusses the history of computing machines, including the Vienna Circle, Hilbert, Godel, Shannon, Turing, von Neumann, Wiener, and the emergence of artificial intelligence. They argue that the computer is a special quasi-machine that can simulate other machines, but that it also "machines" humans in its interaction with them. The author suggests that using computers can be normative and alienating, and that knowing the machine is the only way to avoid being controlled by it. They advocate for deconstructing the machine and bringing active life into the equation to use it in service of humans.

5.13 Dealing with the computational complexity threshold

The author describes how they have used computer simulations to understand the relationships between parallel and distributed processing and behaviors. They argue that this is necessary because humans cannot directly think about processes, but can objectify them through a (quasi) second-order machine. They also discuss the 1948 von Neumann complexity conjecture, which suggests that there is a human complexity threshold beyond which the description of a structure becomes simpler than that of its properties. The author suggests that this is a limitation of the scientist's own cognitive ability to describe complexity. Through bottom-up computer simulation, it is possible to explore emergent behaviors and gain procedural knowledge about the relationship between local properties and global behavior. Finally, the author discusses cognitive limits in dealing with information overload, and suggests that the use of a memory prosthesis can help to overcome this.

5.14 Technologies as externalized and encapsulated gestures

The author discusses the concept of technologies as externalized gestures, which can lead to the progressive loss of human know-how and distance between consciousness and bodily experience. Writing was a first important technological step that expanded democratization, but with the rise of numerical informational technologies and deep learning, our intimate cognitive know-how is being extracted, potentially leading to a loss of savoir vivre and creativity. The current global system is becoming creatively sterile, and the author sees this as an opportunity for human understanding and creativity to flourish.

5.15 The civilized rhythm of formalization and the synchronized logics of mechanical thinkings

The collapse of the Broughton Bridge in 1831 due to soldiers marching in unison illustrates the "mechanical rhythm" of thinking in which form precedes process, a pattern seen in language, logic, and cognitive science. This mode of thinking, in which a gesture of designation coordinates sensory-motor loops, has led to a global resonance between mechanical disciplines such as economics, mathematics, and artificial intelligence, which reinforces cultural and rhetorical power. This resonance has resulted in a crisis of western rationality, contributing to the anthropocene and metacrisis, and revealing that our way of thinking is out of touch with reality.

5.16 Scybernethic(s) and oriental style

The author sees similarities between their way of thinking and some Eastern philosophies, such as the absence of ontology and theology and the idea that reality is in a state of constant change, as seen in traditional Chinese and Taoist thought.

5.17 The quasi-double “middle-way thinking”

The author discusses their understanding of the "middle way" from the Buddhist tradition, which they view as a quasi-bidimensional pathway towards a "slightly unbalanced equilibrium" that allows for life to be active and sensitive. They also describe the middle way in terms of double hermeneutical circles and the "ambijective gesture" that draws distinctions while recognizing interdependence. The author emphasizes that the middle way is not a one-dimensional "grey" synthesis, but a path between nihilism and absolutism.

5.18 Scybernethic(s): designing a second-order rationality as a processual and complex practice

The author describes scybernethic(s) as their rational point of view and a second-order enaction of the enactor and enacting. It is their way of being and seeing the world through double coupled cycles, which is a comprehensive and non-iconoclast second-order rationality. Scybernethic(s) is a regulatory paradigm and an attentional and attentive self-technique dealing with historical, sociological, cultural, and technological constraints with body sense-making and orientation. It involves a co-determined understanding of time in a processual dimensionality.

6. Conclusion

6.1 Drawing a timely and partial synthesis

The author emphasizes the importance of ethics, which is implicit, and proposes a comprehensive second-order rationality, called scybernethics, as a lever to understand all living organisms. This can be achieved through various approaches, such as the dialogical dialectics, the quasi-bidimensional and quasi-quadrilectical forms, and the moëbius-like uroboros pathway. The author suggests that we need to create an attentional and understanding shift and a bifurcation of lived and incarnated humans through a complex second-order phylo-scientific rationality coupled with a democratic bio-techno politics of citizens. The author also notes the need to write a history of theories of self-knowledge.

6.2 The ongoing fouth industrial revolution [and now the more visible genAI disruption 03/23]

The author argues that the current trend of objectifying humans in the human/machine interactive dipole is a fallacy, and that the overuse of metaphors like "memory", "learning", and "intelligence" in describing machines is dangerous. They warn of the excesses of cognitive capitalism and attentional and experiential marketing, and urge for the re-integration of an ethically educated subject into the techno-scientific process. The author also sees opportunities in the access to information and education, and in building a constructive dialogue with emerging oriental cultures.

6.3 Suturing to not forget the forgettings: anamnesia (Plato)

The author argues that our western civilization has prioritized explicit knowledge and technological advancement at the cost of a deeper understanding of the self and the social fabric, leading to a destructive control that is destroying life and resources. They suggest that we need a "pharmakology" of attentional techniques to reconnect with the body and participatory sense-making, and create an attentional care towards our sense of the "commons". The author acknowledges that all is not lost, but we need to prioritize critical, creative, hermeneutical, and ethical self-transforming possibilities.

6.4 Toward interbeing enaction

The author believes that there is important work to be done in studying the similarities and differences between Varela and Simondon to develop an enactive "science of interbeing". However, they caution against subverting the subject/object relation with an abstract and formal third-person "relational realism" ground, as it could lead to techno-economic instrumentalization and the forgetting of the vital dimension. They emphasize the need to be careful not to fall into normativity and instead focus on the possible emancipators of conscious meaning-making embodied in the lived first-person perspective. The author also mentions the promising work of Hanna De Jaegher and Di Paolo around enactive participatory sense-making in developing an enactive approach to ecological and social intersubjectivity.

6.5 A last (auto)po(i)etic word

The author suggests that humans are like the ambijective gesture of nature, trying to be conscious of itself through civilization and personal development. They argue that life is cognition and cognition is life, like a self-reflection of the cosmos. The author believes that it is time to return home with all the revelations of the objectivist journey to share and care. They conclude by stating that ethics should be the priority and is a know-how, while love is defined as having a relationship based on one's interest in the aliveness of the other person.

item.title: Differences and common points of reason and rationality.
item.dc:creator: Christophe_Rigon
item.content:encoded:
• Table of Contents
    • Introduction
    • Exploring the Relationship Between Reason and Rationality in Epistemology
    • Examining the Role of Scientific Knowledge Production in Epistemology
    • Analyzing the Impact of Historical Context on Reason and Rationality
    • Investigating the Philosophical Foundations of Reason and Rationality
    • Comparing and Contrasting Reason and Rationality in Epistemology
"Uncovering the Intersection of Reason and Rationality: an Epistemological Analysis."
Introduction
This paper will provide an epistemological analysis of the differences and common points of reason and rationality. This analysis will be both theoretical and historical, examining the production of scientific knowledge and how it has been shaped by reason and rationality. We will explore the implications of these two concepts, and how they have been used to shape the development of scientific culture. Additionally, the paper will also discuss the implications of this analysis for the future of scientific knowledge production.

Exploring the Relationship Between Reason and Rationality in Epistemology

Epistemology is the study of knowledge and how it is acquired. It is a branch of philosophy that examines the nature of knowledge and how it is acquired. Reason and rationality are two concepts that are closely related in epistemology. Reason is the capacity for logical thought, while rationality is the quality of being reasonable. Both concepts are essential for acquiring knowledge. Reason can be defined as the capacity of human beings to think logically and rationally. It is a fundamental aspect of human cognition, and it plays a central role in scientific inquiry. Scientists use reason to construct hypotheses, design experiments, and analyze data. Reason is also an important tool for evaluating scientific claims and arguments. Rationality, on the other hand, is a broader concept that encompasses not only logical reasoning but also other cognitive processes, such as intuition, perception, and emotion. Rationality involves the use of reason in the context of practical decision-making, and it is closely related to the concept of critical thinking. While reason and rationality are both important for scientific inquiry, they differ in their scope and purpose. Reason is primarily concerned with the logical coherence of arguments and the validity of conclusions, whereas rationality is concerned with the practical consequences of decisions and actions.

Examining the Role of Scientific Knowledge Production in Epistemology

The production of scientific knowledge has long been a cornerstone of epistemology, the branch of philosophy that deals with the nature of knowledge and how it is acquired. Scientific knowledge production is a complex process that involves the collection and analysis of data, the formulation of hypotheses, and the testing of those hypotheses through experimentation. This process is essential to the advancement of scientific understanding and the development of new theories and technologies. At its core, scientific knowledge production is a process of inquiry. Scientists ask questions about the natural world and seek to answer them through observation, experimentation, and analysis. This process is guided by the scientific method, which involves the formulation of a hypothesis, the collection of data, and the testing of the hypothesis through experimentation. Through this process, scientists are able to gain a better understanding of the natural world and develop new theories and technologies. The production of scientific knowledge is also an important part of epistemology. By examining the process of scientific inquiry, philosophers are able to gain insight into the nature of knowledge and how it is acquired. This process helps to identify the sources of knowledge and the methods by which it is acquired. It also helps to identify the limitations of scientific knowledge and the ways in which it can be improved.

Analyzing the Impact of Historical Context on Reason and Rationality

Throughout history, reason and rationality have been shaped by the context in which they are applied. From the ancient Greeks to the Enlightenment, the way in which reason and rationality are understood and used has been heavily influenced by the prevailing cultural, political, and religious beliefs of the time. The ancient Greeks, for example, believed that reason and rationality were the highest forms of knowledge and that they could be used to understand the world around them. This led to the development of the scientific method, which relied on observation and experimentation to uncover the truth. The Greeks also believed that reason and rationality could be used to make moral decisions, and this led to the development of ethical theories such as utilitarianism. The Enlightenment period saw a shift in the way reason and rationality were viewed. This period was marked by a focus on individualism and the belief that reason and rationality could be used to create a better society. This led to the development of the concept of human rights and the idea that individuals should be free to pursue their own interests. The Industrial Revolution also had an impact on reason and rationality. This period saw the rise of the scientific method and the development of new technologies that allowed for the mass production of goods. This led to a greater emphasis on efficiency and the belief that reason and rationality could be used to create a more efficient society. Finally, the modern era has seen a shift in the way reason and rationality are viewed. This period has seen a greater emphasis on the importance of emotion and intuition in decision-making. This has led to the development of new theories such as behavioral economics, which focus on the role of emotions in decision-making. Overall, it is clear that the historical context in which reason and rationality are applied has had a significant impact on the way they are understood and used. From the ancient Greeks to the modern era, the way in which reason and rationality are viewed has been heavily influenced by the prevailing cultural, political, and religious beliefs of the time. As such, it is important to consider the historical context when examining the impact of reason and rationality on society.

Investigating the Philosophical Foundations of Reason and Rationality

Reason and rationality are two of the most fundamental philosophical concepts, and have been the subject of debate and discussion for centuries. They are closely intertwined, yet distinct in their own right. Reason is the capacity for logical thought, while rationality is the application of reason to make decisions. Reason is the ability to think logically and draw conclusions from evidence. It is the capacity to understand the world around us and to make sense of it. Reason is the basis for all knowledge and understanding, and is essential for making decisions. It is the foundation of science, philosophy, and all other forms of knowledge. Rationality is the application of reason to make decisions. It is the ability to think logically and objectively, and to make decisions based on evidence and logical reasoning. Rationality is the basis for all ethical and moral decisions, and is essential for making decisions that are in the best interests of oneself and others. Reason and rationality are closely intertwined, yet distinct in their own right. Reason is the capacity for logical thought, while rationality is the application of reason to make decisions. Reason is the foundation of knowledge and understanding, while rationality is the basis for ethical and moral decisions. Reason and rationality are essential for making decisions that are in the best interests of oneself and others. Reason and rationality are essential for making decisions that are in the best interests of oneself and others. They are the basis for all knowledge and understanding, and are essential for making decisions that are based on evidence and logical reasoning. Reason and rationality are the foundation of science, philosophy, and all other forms of knowledge, and are essential for making decisions that are ethical and moral. Reason and rationality are the cornerstones of a just and equitable society, and are essential for making decisions that are in the best interests of all.

Comparing and Contrasting Reason and Rationality in Epistemology

Epistemology is the branch of philosophy that deals with the nature of knowledge and how it is acquired. Reason and rationality are two important concepts in epistemology, and while they are related, they are distinct. Reason is the capacity of the mind to think, understand, and form judgments based on evidence and logic. Rationality is the quality of being reasonable and consistent in thought and action. Reason is the basis for forming judgments and making decisions. It is the ability to think logically and draw conclusions based on evidence. Reason is the foundation of knowledge, as it allows us to make sense of the world around us and form valid conclusions. Reason is also the basis for moral decision-making, as it allows us to evaluate the consequences of our actions and make decisions that are in line with our values. Rationality, on the other hand, is the quality of being reasonable and consistent in thought and action. It is the ability to think logically and make decisions based on evidence and logic. Rationality is the basis for making decisions that are in line with our values and beliefs. It is the ability to think critically and objectively, and to make decisions that are in our best interests. In conclusion, reason and rationality are two important concepts in epistemology. Reason is the capacity of the mind to think, understand, and form judgments based on evidence and logic. Rationality is the quality of being reasonable, logical, and consistent in thought and action. Both are essential for forming valid conclusions and making decisions that are in line with our values and beliefs.

item.title: Exploring the Future of Rationality at the Age of ChatGPT
item.dc:creator: Christophe_Rigon
item.content:encoded:
A conversation with ChatGPT4 about cognitive functionalism, mechanical thinking, the enactive paradigm and their systemic implications both on our world and on our common rationality.

“We succeeded, and we failed, for exactly the same reason, namely our mode of rationality.”

J. A. Wojciechowski.

The deep civilizational roots of functionalism and mechanical thinking

Me: "Explain the epistemological relation between cognitive functionalism and mechanical thinking, both in a theoretical and historical sense."

ChatGPT4:
"Epistemology is the branch of philosophy that deals with the nature, scope, and sources of knowledge. To understand the epistemological relation between cognitive functionalism and mechanical thinking, we need to delve into their theoretical and historical origins, as well as how they inform our understanding of the mind and cognition.

Cognitive functionalism emerged in the mid-20th century as a reaction to behaviorism, which dominated psychology at the time. Behaviorism posited that mental states were not scientifically observable, and therefore, should not be part of scientific inquiry. Functionalism, on the other hand, focused on the mental processes and functions that underlie behavior, emphasizing that the mind is an information-processing system.

Functionalism has strong connections to computationalism, the idea that the mind can be understood as a computational system, akin to a computer. This perspective aligns with mechanical thinking, which dates back to ancient Greece and has evolved over time. Mechanical thinking posits that natural phenomena, including mental processes, can be explained through the principles of mechanics, such as cause and effect.

Historically, mechanical thinking began with philosophers like Democritus, who proposed that the world is composed of indivisible atoms governed by mechanical laws. This idea was further developed by Descartes, who proposed that the universe, including living organisms, operates like a machine. In the 17th and 18th centuries, Newton's laws of motion and the development of classical mechanics further solidified mechanical thinking as a dominant worldview in science and philosophy. This mechanistic perspective influenced the development of cognitive functionalism, as it provided a framework for understanding mental processes through the lens of computational systems and information processing.

The epistemological relation between cognitive functionalism and mechanical thinking is that both aim to understand and explain mental processes through objective, systematic, and quantifiable methods. Cognitive functionalism builds on the foundation of mechanical thinking by treating the mind as a complex information-processing system, often drawing parallels to computers and other machines.

In cognitive functionalism, mental processes and states are explained in terms of their function and the way they process information, rather than their physical or biological makeup. This idea shares an epistemological connection to mechanical thinking, as both seek to uncover the underlying principles and operations governing mental phenomena, often through the use of formal models and computational simulations.

In conclusion, cognitive functionalism and mechanical thinking share an epistemological relation that stems from their common goal of understanding the mind and cognition through systematic, quantifiable, and objective means. Cognitive functionalism builds on the historical foundations of mechanical thinking by applying the principles of information processing and computational systems to the study of mental processes. Both approaches aim to provide a rigorous and mechanistic account of the mind, contributing to our overall understanding of cognition and the nature of knowledge."

The global consequences of an excessive functionalist and mechanical rationality on our societies

Me: "What are the systemic and global consequences of an excessive functionalist and mechanical rationality on our societies?"

ChatGPT4:

"An excessive functionalist and mechanical rationality can have several systemic and global consequences on our societies. While these approaches have been instrumental in driving advancements in science, technology, and industry, they can also lead to unintended negative consequences.

Some potential consequences of an excessive functionalist and mechanical rationality include:

  1. Reductionism: Overemphasis on breaking down complex phenomena into simpler components can lead to a reductionist view of reality. This reductionism might cause us to overlook important interactions and emergent properties that arise from the complexity of social and natural systems.
  2. Dehumanization: A mechanistic worldview can result in a dehumanized perspective, treating individuals as mere components of a larger system rather than as unique, conscious beings. This can lead to a disregard for the subjective experiences and emotions of people, affecting social relationships and ethical considerations.
  3. Environmental degradation: The focus on efficiency, productivity, and technological progress can contribute to the exploitation of natural resources and environmental degradation. The mechanistic view may treat the environment as a mere resource to be used, rather than as a complex, interconnected ecosystem that needs to be protected and preserved.
  4. Alienation: The emphasis on rationality and quantification can lead to feelings of alienation and disconnection from our inner selves, nature, and others, reducing the importance of subjective experiences, intuition, and empathy in decision-making processes.

How can the Enactive paradigm help re-harmonizing the balance?

Me: "Compare the preceding with an enactive rationality (Francisco Varela)."

ChatGPT4:

"In contrast, Francisco Varela's enactive approach offers an alternative perspective on rationality, cognition, and the relationship between the mind and the environment. The enactive approach, rooted in phenomenology and first-person experience, emphasizes the following aspects:

  1. Embodiment: Enactive rationality highlights the importance of the body in cognition, asserting that our thinking is deeply grounded in our physical experiences and interactions with the world. This view recognizes the role of emotions, sensations, and intuition in shaping our understanding of reality.
  2. Embeddedness: The enactive approach posits that cognition is not an isolated process occurring solely within the brain but is instead embedded within and influenced by the broader social, cultural, and environmental contexts.
  3. Emergence: Enactive rationality acknowledges the complexity of natural and social systems and the emergent properties that arise from the interactions between their components. This perspective values the importance of understanding phenomena holistically rather than reducing them to their constituent parts.
  4. Co-creation: The enactive approach emphasizes the role of individuals in co-creating their reality through their interactions with the environment and other living beings. This perspective recognizes the importance of human agency, values, and ethics in shaping the world.

By comparing the potential consequences of excessive functionalist and mechanical rationality with the enactive approach, we can see that the enactive perspective offers a more holistic and human-centered understanding of cognition, reality, and our relationship with the environment. The enactive approach encourages a greater appreciation for the complexity and interconnectedness of natural and social systems, the role of subjective experiences, emotions, and embodiment in shaping our understanding of the world, and the importance of ethical considerations in our actions and decisions.

The systemic and global consequences of adopting an enactive rationality might include:

  1. Greater emphasis on well-being: By valuing subjective experiences and emotions, an enactive approach could lead to a greater focus on mental health, happiness, and overall well-being in societal decision-making processes.
  2. Holistic problem-solving: Addressing complex global challenges, such as climate change, poverty, and social inequality, may benefit from the enactive approach's appreciation for emergent properties and the interconnectedness of systems. This could result in more comprehensive and sustainable solutions.
  3. Ethical and value-based considerations: The recognition of human agency and co-creation of reality in the enactive approach can lead to greater emphasis on ethical considerations and values in decision-making processes, promoting social responsibility and accountability.
  4. Improved social cohesion: By acknowledging the importance of social and cultural contexts in cognition, the enactive approach could foster greater understanding and empathy among individuals from diverse backgrounds, promoting social cohesion and inclusivity."

Summary

"In summary, while functionalist and mechanical rationality have been key drivers of scientific and technological progress, their excessive focus can lead to negative consequences, such as reductionism, dehumanization, environmental degradation, and alienation. The enactive approach, as proposed by Francisco Varela, offers an alternative perspective that values embodiment, embeddedness, emergence, and co-creation. Adopting enactive rationality could result in a greater emphasis on well-being, holistic problem-solving, ethical considerations, and social cohesion, ultimately promoting more sustainable, inclusive, and human-centered societies.

However, it is essential to recognize that neither approach should be taken to an extreme, as each has its merits and limitations. Striking a balance between functionalist-mechanical rationality and enactive rationality can lead to a more nuanced understanding of the world and enable us to address complex global challenges more effectively, while also fostering a deeper connection with ourselves, others, and the environment."

item.title: In search of the Origins of the Meaning Crisis
item.dc:creator: Christophe_Rigon
item.content:encoded:
Heidegger's "attunement" and the meaning crisis

Me: "How can we use Martin Heidegger's "attunement" to understand the origin of the actual meaning crisis (John Vervaeke)?"

ChatGPT4:

"To use Martin Heidegger's concept of "attunement" to understand the origin of the actual meaning crisis, as discussed by John Vervaeke, we can explore how the background moods and existential situations in contemporary society have influenced people's experiences and understanding of meaning in their lives.

  1. Technological and informational overload: The rapid advancement of technology and the information age have led to an overwhelming amount of information and stimuli, which can make it difficult for individuals to maintain a clear sense of purpose and meaning. This informational overload might contribute to a general attunement of anxiety, disorientation, or a sense of being lost in the face of endless possibilities and options.
  2. Loss of traditional structures: As traditional social, religious, and cultural frameworks have weakened in modern society, many people find themselves without the guidance and support these structures once provided. The loss of these shared frameworks can create a pervasive attunement of uncertainty and disconnection, contributing to the meaning crisis as individuals struggle to construct coherent narratives for their lives.
  3. Consumerism and materialism: The rise of consumerism and materialism as dominant cultural values can create an attunement focused on acquiring material possessions and wealth, rather than cultivating deeper connections, personal growth, or spiritual development. This attunement might contribute to a sense of emptiness and dissatisfaction, as the pursuit of external markers of success does not necessarily lead to a meaningful and fulfilling life.
  4. Fragmentation and isolation: The increasing fragmentation and isolation in contemporary society, resulting from factors such as urbanization, individualism, and the erosion of communal life, can lead to an attunement characterized by loneliness, disconnection, and alienation. This can exacerbate the meaning crisis as individuals struggle to find meaningful relationships and connections in their lives.

By examining the various attunements in modern society, we can gain a better understanding of how the background moods and existential situations have contributed to the current meaning crisis. Recognizing these factors can help us address the underlying issues and seek solutions that promote a more meaningful, authentic, and fulfilling way of life.

John Vervaeke's work on the meaning crisis provides complementary insights and potential pathways for cultivating meaning and overcoming the crisis. By combining insights from Heidegger's attunement and Vervaeke's work on relevance realization, cognitive science, and wisdom cultivation, we can develop a more holistic understanding of the meaning crisis and explore ways to foster a more meaningful existence in the contemporary world."

Martin Heidegger's "attunement" vs John Vervaeke "Relevance Realization"

Me: "What is Martin Heidegger 'attunement'? Compare it to John Vervaeke Relevance Realization."

ChatGPT4:

"Martin Heidegger's concept of "attunement" (Stimmung or mood) is a central aspect of his existential philosophy, particularly as it appears in his magnum opus, "Being and Time." Attunement, for Heidegger, refers to the fundamental way in which we find ourselves in the world, the pre-reflective and pre-conceptual background mood that shapes our experience and understanding of our existence.

Heidegger posits that our attunement is not merely an individual or subjective phenomenon but rather discloses the world in a certain way, revealing its significance and meaning. In other words, our mood discloses our existential situation and determines our openness to or concealment of certain aspects of reality. Heidegger emphasizes that our attunement is often concealed and overlooked because it is so deeply embedded in our everyday experiences.

John Vervaeke's concept of "relevance realization" is a key element of his cognitive science-based framework for understanding meaning-making and wisdom cultivation. Relevance realization is the process by which our cognitive systems dynamically and adaptively select, organize, and integrate information to construct meaningful experiences, solve problems, and navigate the world. It involves the ongoing, real-time adjustment and fine-tuning of our attention, perception, and cognition to maximize our ability to engage with what is most relevant and important in a given context.

While both Heidegger's attunement and Vervaeke's relevance realization address aspects of human experience and meaning-making, they stem from different intellectual traditions and emphasize different aspects. Heidegger's attunement is rooted in existential philosophy and focuses on the affective, pre-reflective background that shapes our understanding of our existence and world. In contrast, Vervaeke's relevance realization is grounded in cognitive science and concentrates on the cognitive processes by which we construct meaning and navigate the complexities of our environment.

Despite these differences, there are some connections between the two concepts. Both Heidegger and Vervaeke emphasize the importance of context in shaping human experience and understanding. Attunement affects how we disclose and engage with the world, while relevance realization involves the adaptive selection and organization of information in response to contextual demands. Additionally, both thinkers recognize that human experience is not static but is rather an ongoing, dynamic process of engagement with the world."

Scybernethic(s) as a phenomenology of Gesture

Me: "Imagine a thinking framework, let's call it "scybernethics" or second-order enaction, that posit that gesture agency and attention are the roots an homeostatic approach of meaning and affective valence. Compare it to the two preceding conceptions. What does it imply about the search for scientific objectivity and truth?"

ChatGPT4:

""Scybernethics" or second-order enaction, as a hypothetical thinking framework, proposes that gesture agency and attention form the basis of a homeostatic approach to meaning and affective valence. This framework suggests that our actions, gestures, and the direction of our attention play a crucial role in determining our experience of meaning and affect. In essence, scybernethics emphasizes the importance of the active, embodied, and dynamic nature of human cognition and experience.

When compared to Heidegger's attunement and Vervaeke's relevance realization, scybernethics seems to share some common ground. All three frameworks highlight the significance of context and the dynamic, adaptive nature of human experience. Heidegger's attunement focuses on the affective, pre-reflective background that discloses our existential situation, while Vervaeke's relevance realization deals with the cognitive processes that construct meaning and adapt to contextual demands. Scybernethics, on the other hand, emphasizes the role of embodied action and attention in shaping meaning and affect.

In terms of the search for scientific objectivity and truth, scybernethics could have several implications. Firstly, by emphasizing the role of embodied action and attention, scybernethics suggests that our understanding of the world is intrinsically tied to our active engagement with it. This perspective challenges the traditional assumption that scientific objectivity can be achieved by detaching the observer from the observed.

Secondly, the focus on the dynamic and adaptive nature of meaning and affect implies that scientific objectivity and truth are not static, fixed entities but are rather contingent on the evolving context and the active role of the observer. This view is consistent with contemporary perspectives on scientific inquiry, which emphasize the importance of considering the historical, cultural, and social context in which scientific knowledge is produced.

Finally, by highlighting the importance of gesture agency and attention, scybernethics implies that the search for scientific objectivity and truth is not merely a cognitive process but also involves affective and embodied aspects. This perspective encourages a more holistic and integrative approach to scientific inquiry, which acknowledges the complex interplay between cognitive, affective, and embodied factors in shaping our understanding of the world.

Overall, scybernethics suggests that the pursuit of scientific objectivity and truth is deeply intertwined with the dynamic, embodied, and contextual nature of human experience. This perspective can enrich our understanding of scientific inquiry by encouraging a more nuanced and integrative approach to the study of the natural world."

Extending your knowledge of the Meaning Crisis

item.title: Whence perceptual meaning? A cartography of current ideas - Varela F. J. (1991)
item.dc:creator: Christophe_Rigon
item.content:encoded:
Varela F. J. (1991) Whence perceptual meaning? A cartography of current ideas. In: Varela F. J. & Dupuy J. P. (eds.) Understanding origins: Contemporary ideas on the origin of life, mind and society. Kluwer, Boston: 235–263.

Available at https://cepa.info/2074 (free inscription, excellent knowledge base about enaction and alternative approaches to cognition).

Also published as a little book, in French: "Connaître - Les Sciences cognitives, tendances et perspectives" (Ed. Seuil, 1989), renamed "Invitation aux Sciences Cognitives" (Ed. Seuil, Point Science, 1996). But, sadly, it doesn't seems that there is an English book version, so enjoy!

My personal comments and today's enaction (optional)

This text has been on my my bedside table for years and even if the field has of course evolved in thirty years, most of it's assertions and analysis are still valid today.

You will understand that the traditional scientific way of thinking is exemplified by the dominant, orthodox and intellectual "Cognitivism", that the so-called "Deep Learning" techs are just one intermediary ("(neo)Connexionist") way of seeing cognition, and that all these could be integrated into a comprehensive, embodied and situated approach: "Enaction".

More, studying and practicing these 3 "ways of seeing", and understanding their complementarity and useful respective contexts, is crucial and essential. Developing epistemological flexibility, an ability to navigate appropriately between these three points of view is the key to:

1. Potentially interpret any discourse about "cognition" or about "what is intelligence" but also to virtually conceptualize nearly any style of cognitive/"intelligent" system.

2. Understand and decode on what implicit and tacit preconceptions they rely ("metaphysical standpoint"), what Noopolitics & Technopolitics is at stake, what is missing.

3. And may be more importantly, to have beacons to reflect on your own thinking style.

>>> Trust me, if you ever had just one text to read (and study) about Cognitive Sciences in your life, it would be this one. And be patient if these views don't "click" immediately in your mind, it's absolutely normal, but don't forget to come back to this essential synthetic reference. It will worth all the time you will put in it to familiarize yourself with them, and with you).

N.B.:

1. In this context it should be noted that here the term "symbol" doesn't refer to it's traditional and religious/spiritual/artistic sense (inner/outer synchronic meaningful evocation) but more to a kind of semiotic and relational sense as a physical "sign" (cf. Newell & Simon), devoid of embodied meaning.

2. One big absent of this overview is the Human & Social Sciences point of view, more covered by Dupuy (CREA). This is addressed more explicitly today by the "participatory sense-making" dimension (De Jaegher, Di Paolo) and the enactive ecological approach of psychology (Maiese), but also on the technical side by people like, for example, Havelange and Lenay (Compiègne School of enaction) in France. There is also others recent and exciting enactive approaches toward Philosophy (Thompson), Developmental & Neuro Biology (Ciaunica), Psychology (Renault), Phenomenology (Vörös, Bitbol, Depraz, Petitmengin), Physics (QuEn), Ecology (Weber), Human-machines interactions, Archeology, ... and even a new "Irruption theory" (Froese), Art Philosophy & Aesthetic (Alva Noë) and love, just to name a few in my restricted field of view. Enactive scientists and thinkers are inherently multidisciplinary and powerful interface catalysts. Today's Enaction is definitively alive and kicking!

But let's dive into this masterpiece of a great and remarkable open-minded and visionary scientist:
